title: Free-body diagram - object moves at constant speed

content.question: A student pushes a block of mass <math alttext="M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> over a rough horizontal surface at a constant velocity of <math alttext="3 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mtext> m/s</mtext></math> to the right, as shown in the figure. A free-body diagram of just the horizontal forces exerted on the block is also shown. A larger block of mass <math alttext="2 M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is then placed on top of the smaller block. The student again pushes the smaller block so that both blocks move together with the same constant velocity of <math alttext="3 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mtext> m/s</mtext></math> to the right. Which of the following free-body diagrams best represents the horizontal forces exerted on the bottom block in the second situation? The arrows representing the forces are all drawn to scale.

choices.label: The figure shows a dot at the center of a 6 by 2 grid. There are 2 arrows extending from the dot. One arrow extends one unit to the left, and one arrow extends one unit to the right.
The figure shows a dot in a 6 by 2 gridded plane. Two arrows are extending from the dot. One arrow extends 3 units to the left, and one arrow extends 3 units to the right.

The figure shows a dot at the center of a 6 by 2 grid. There are 3 arrows extending from the dot. One arrow extends one unit to the left, one arrow extends two units to the left, and one arrow extends three units to the right.

The figure shows a dot at the center of a 6 by 2 grid. There are 3 arrows extending from the dot. One arrow extends three units to the left, one arrow extends one unit to the right, and one arrow extends two units to the right.

content.answer: The figure shows a dot in a 6 by 2 gridded plane. Two arrows are extending from the dot. One arrow extends 3 units to the left, and one arrow extends 3 units to the right.
